I.  INTRODUCTION 
   
1.  The  Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  requested  Asian 
Development Bank (ADB) assistance to prepare the proposed Inner Mongolia Autonomous 
Region  Environmental  Improvement  Project  (Phase  II).  The  concept  paper  for  project 
preparatory technical assistance (TA) was approved on 2 May 2007. A fact-finding mission 
visited the PRC from 19 to 28 May and reached an agreement with the Government on the 
objectives, scope, cost estimates, financing plan, and implementation arrangements of the TA.1 
The TA design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.  
 
II.  ISSUES 
 
2.  The PRC energy supply is heavily dependent on coal, which makes up 69% of the 
primary  energy  supply.  The  heavy  dependence  on  coal  has  resulted  in  substantial 
environmental damage caused by emissions such as sulfur dioxide (SO ), nitrogen oxides (NO ), 
2 x
total suspended particulates (TSP), and other harmful emissions. SO  and NO  are the main 
2 x
precursor gases that cause acid rain, one of the largest environmental problems in the PRC, 
TSP causes serious public health impacts. CO , which is a major emission from coal burning, is 
2
a major cause of global warming. Air pollution alone is estimated to result in an annual loss of 
1.3% of gross domestic product (GDP) for the PRC economy. The Inner Mongolia Autonomous 
Region (IMAR) is heavily dependent on coal use with coal supplying 92% of the primary energy 
supply and 95% of energy for heating purposes (2006). In 2005, IMAR discharged 1.46 million 
tons of SO , representing 5.7% of the national emission, although the IMAR population is only 
2
1.8% of the national total. Coal burning by households contributes an estimated 6% of IMAR 
annual SO  emissions. Reliance on coal has a high environmental cost for urban areas in IMAR 
2
with only 6 of its 20 cities reaching class II air quality standards (2006) and large areas being 
impacted by acid rain. 
 
3.  Demand for district heating is growing rapidly in the PRC through increased incomes 
and privatization of residential housing. Low rise residential buildings that are expensive to 
supply with district heating are rapidly being replaced with high rise residential buildings more 
suitable for district heating. Urbanization and increased demand for district heating is also 
increasing  in  IMAR  due  to  Government  relocation  policies  for  animal  herders  to  reduce 
environmental pressure on fragile pasture lands. IMAR has a total population of 23.86 million; 
the urban population increased from 42.2% in 2000 to 47.2% in 2005. As a consequence, the 
district heating area is expanding rapidly, increasing by 19% between 2003 and 2004 and a 
further 23% between 2004 and 2005. A large proportion of the existing heating systems are 
small capacity, highly polluting, inefficient, neighborhood coal-fired boilers, and an aging pipe 
network with high distribution losses. In many urban areas the district heating systems were 
installed in the 1970s and have exceeded their design lives, resulting in high distribution losses 
and unreliable services. Additionally, due to relatively poor economic conditions, remote areas 
have inadequate heating supply; this has a proportionally high impact on the poor.  
 
4.  The  low  efficiency  of  the  existing  IMAR  heating  systems,  both  in  generation  and 
distribution, leads directly to environmental impacts from emissions because of increased coal 
consumption.  The  PRC  Government  recognizes  the  importance  of  improving  the  energy 
efficiency of the economy. The PRC 11th Five-Year Plan mandates a 20% reduction in energy 
intensity by 2010. During 2006, energy intensity of the PRC economy reduced by 1.23%, which 
increased the improvement required in the remaining 4 years. The IMAR target is to improve 
                                                 
1  The TA first appeared in ADB Business Opportunities on 3 May 2007.

2   
energy intensity by 25% by 2010. This will be a major challenge considering IMAR uses 2.48 
tons of standard coal equivalent per CNY10,000 of GDP, as opposed to the national average of 
1.22 (2005). Large energy efficiency gains are available from the district heating subsector 
through system replacement and upgrading of the heat production and distribution systems. For 
example, small heating boilers typically have efficiencies of about 40%, while new larger boilers 
have efficiencies exceeding 80%. Additional opportunities for improving energy efficiency and 
reducing  environmental  impact  in  district  heating  include  (i)  utilizing  alternative  renewable 
energy  sources,  such  as  geothermal  energy;  and  (ii)  capturing  waste  heat  from  existing 
industrial processes.   
 
5.  Provision of reliable, affordable household heating is a basic necessity in IMAR due to 
severe winter conditions, when temperatures can fall to as low as minus 40o Celsius, and the 
heating season can extend for 7 months. Environmental impacts from the current heating 
methods have a disproportionately high impact on the poor. Inadequate coverage of district 
heating to low income urban areas results in use of indoor coal burning for heating purposes, 
which is a major cause of respiratory disease. Urban pollution from small local boilers also 
reduces outdoor air quality and has a significant cumulative negative impact on public health. 
IMAR has 31 national poverty counties and 29 provincial poverty counties with 697,000 people 
living below the poverty line (2005). The cost of heating for the poor is relatively high. For 
example, a typical family living at the poverty line in a remote area of IMAR could expect to pay 
around 20%–30% of annual income on heating bills. The Mongol population, at 4.1 million, 
accounts for 17.6% of the total IMAR population (2005); this percentage is higher in the remote 
and poorer areas. The initial poverty and social analysis is presented in Appendix 2.  
 
6.  Local government financial resources and central Government support are inadequate to 
meet the large investment requirements in the IMAR heating subsector. In particular, the more 
remote municipalities and counties lack financial resources to replace and expand existing 
heating systems. Private sector involvement has been relatively slow, due to (i) reluctance to 
privatize the delivery of an essential public service; (ii) relatively low financial return, (iii) small 
size of operations in smaller urban areas; and (iv) reluctance of local financial institutions to 
provide financing, particularly in smaller more remote urban areas. A range of barriers need to 
be analyzed and addressed to encourage private sector participation in district heating. The TA 
will continue ADB policy dialogue on district heating reform to develop the enabling environment.  
 
7.  The Government is working to address the impact of environmental issues and low 
energy efficiency of the economy. The proposed project supports the following 11th Five-Year 
Plan targets: (i) decrease SO  emissions by 10% by reducing coal consumption; (ii) improve 
2
energy efficiency by 20% per unit GDP by replacing obsolete and inefficient boilers, improve 
efficiency of district heating distribution networks, recover industrial waste heat, and utilize 
renewable energy; and (iii) optimize development of renewable energy resources. The TA will 
also (i) provide policy advice to several levels of government on improving the efficiency of 
public utility services, (ii) strengthen the institutional capacity of the executing and implementing 
agencies, and (iii) help improve corporate governance and financial management of local heat 
suppliers.  
 
8.  The proposed project is consistent with (i) the strategic priority of ADB’s Medium-Term 
Strategy  II,  2006–2008  of  managing  the  environment,2 and  (ii)  the  strategic  development 
objective of the PRC country strategy and program to improve the environment.3 The proposed 
                                                 
2  ADB. 2006. Medium Term Strategy II 2006-2008. Manila 
3  ADB. 2003. Country Strategy and Program (2004–2006): People’s Republic of China. Manila.

3
project will build on continuing engagement in the heating subsector, including a number of 
recent advisory TA projects.4 In December 2006, ADB approved a project5 (2006 project) that 
targets district heating and gas distribution in Bayannur, Erdos and Wuhai districts of IMAR. The 
proposed project will assist the government of the IMAR (GIMAR) in extending improved and 
diversified district heating and gas supply to other urban areas, including more remote and 
poorer municipalities and counties. The proposed project will incorporate recommendations and 
lessons from the previous advisory TAs and the 2006 project.    
 
9.  Previous ADB projects targeting environment improvements in the energy sector provide 
many lessons. In some projects, initial heating demand forecasts were inaccurate; this led to 
subsequent canceling of heating subprojects. In some industrial projects, technologies could not 
be properly transferred due to technical incompatibilities with PRC industrial conditions. The 
proposed project will address these issues by (i) undertaking a detailed demand analysis for all 
subprojects, and (ii) ensuring that all central heating systems are based on demonstrated 
technology currently being operated in the PRC. Risks will be carefully assessed during project 
preparation by incorporating lessons identified from earlier projects for design, preparation, risk 
assessment, and implementation.  
 
10.  During preparation of the 2006 project, some processing delays were experienced due 
to the poor quality of the prefeasibility studies. Several separate design institutes were engaged 
to prepare different subprojects, which made ensuring consistent quality difficult. Further, some 
implementing agencies had relatively low project development capacity. This project preparatory 
TA will address these issues by (i) screening design institutes that will prepare the feasibility 
studies, thereby reducing the number of design institutes and improving quality; (ii) conducting 
training sessions for implementing agencies on ADB procedures and anticipated schedules; and 
(iii) helping the design institutes with reviews from an early stage. GIMAR is the executing 
agency for the project preparatory TA, as it is for the 2006 project, and the majority of staff at 
the Project Management Office will be retained for TA implementation. This should ensure 
consistency and improve processing efficiency.   
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
11.  The impact of the TA will be improved environment of 13 IMAR urban areas through 
increased efficiency of the district heating and gas distribution systems. The outcome of the TA 
will be an agreement between the central Government and ADB on project design, feasibility 
study, and implementation arrangements for an ensuing project.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
 
12.  The TA will (i) assess IMAR’s district heating subsector; (ii) carry out a demand forecast, 
including  least-cost  system  planning;  (iii)  evaluate  the  technical  feasibility  and  engineering

aspects of the proposed project; (iv) provide cost estimates and procurement arrangements, 
and prepare a contract packaging plan; (v) carry out the economic and financial analyses; (vi) 
prepare the environmental impact assessment, and land acquisition and resettlement plan; and 
provide summaries of each; (vii) analyze the financial governance and financial performance of 
the implementing agencies; (viii) recommend necessary enterprise and sector reforms, and 
assess  areas  for  policy  dialogue;  (ix)  conduct  consultation  and  participation  activities;  (x) 
undertake capacity training activities; (xi) evaluate the poverty impact and identify ways to make 
the proposed project more pro-poor; (xii) establish indicators which can be readily monitored 
and a monitoring mechanism; and (xiii) recommend measures to encourage private sector 
participation in the IMAR heating subsector. 
 
13.  The major assumptions in the proposed project design include (i) the Government and 
ADB will sign the loan agreement, (ii) stakeholders effectively engage in the proposed project, 
(iii) the Government establishes effective ownership over the proposed project, and (iv) the 
implementing agencies allows full access to relevant documentation. Efforts will be made to 
engage stakeholders at an early stage to ensure support. Careful consultant selection and 
ongoing supervision will ensure that quality consultants are selected and reports are delivered 
according to schedule. Risks include that the schedule may be impacted by delay in consultant 
recruitment  or  an  early  winter.  Early  consultant  recruitment  will  ensure  that  field  work  is 
completed prior to the 2006–2007 winter season.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
14.  The TA is estimated to cost $1,000,000 equivalent. ADB will finance $800,000 on a grant 
basis from ADB's TA funding program, and GIMAR will finance $200,000. Details of the cost 
estimates and financing plan are given in Appendix 3. The Government has been informed that 
provision of the TA does not commit ADB to finance any ensuing project. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
15.  The TA will be carried out by a consulting firm with experience in district heating supply, 
institutional reform, economic analysis, financial analysis, environmental assessment, and social 
impact analysis. The six international consultants (combined 15 person-months) will include (i) 
district heating specialist, (ii) private sector development specialist, (iii) economist, (iv) financial 
and  institutional  analyst,  (v)  geothermal  specialist,  and  (vi)  environment  specialist.  The  13 
national consultants (combined 46 person-months) will include (i) district heating specialist, (ii) 
private sector development specialists, (iii) economist, (iv) financial and institutional analysts, (v) 
geothermal  specialist,  (vi)  natural  gas  distribution  specialist,  (vii)  social  and  resettlement 
specialists, (viii) environment specialist, and (ix) project monitoring specialist. The consultants 
will submit the following reports: (i) inception report in week 10, (ii) draft final report in week 18, 
and (iii) final report in week 28. Tripartite meetings will be held after the consultants submit the 
inception, draft final, and final reports. International and national consultants will be selected and 
engaged in accordance with ADB Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2007, as amended 
from time to time). The services of consultants will be provided through a consulting firm 
selected after the submission of simplified technical proposals and the use of quality and cost-
based  selection  methods  (technical  proposals  80%,  financial  proposals  20%).  The  TA  is 
expected to commence in October 2007 and be completed by April 2008. The outline terms of 
reference are presented in Appendix 4.  
 
16.  GIMAR will assign the project management office of the 2006 project the responsibility to 
coordinate TA implementation, and will provide suitable increases in resource allocation. Where

5
possible, the existing facilities and staff of the existing Project Management Office will be utilized. 
GIMAR has agreed to provide interpreters, local transportation, and office space in Hohhot 
equipped with suitable facilities. Some of the office equipment will be financed under the TA and 
be  procured  by  the  international  consultants  in  accordance  with  ADB  Guidelines  for 
Procurement (2007, as amended from time to time). The equipment will be turned over to the 
GIMAR upon completion of the TA. Workshops and seminars will be undertaken to improve 
capacity of project stakeholders, including implementing agencies, and assist in coordinating the 
TA.   
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
17.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $800,000 on a grant basis to 
the  Government  of  the  People’s  Republic  of  China  for  Preparing  the  Inner  Mongolia 
Autonomous Region Environment  Improvement Project (Phase II), and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.

A.  Linkages to the Country Poverty Analysis

Contribution of the sector or subsector to reduce poverty in the People’s Republic of China (PRC): 
 
Improved heat supply and gas distribution in 13 cities and towns in the Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region may 
improve the efficiency of energy supply by at least 25%. The heating supply companies will be in a position to share 
these efficiency gains with poor urban consumers by lowering tariffs without compromising profitability. Upgrading and 
expanding the urban heating and gas supply systems will benefit urban residents, particularly the urban poor, by 
improving heating coverage and improving reliability and cost of supply.  
 
B.  Poverty Analysis   Proposed Targeting Classification: General intervention  
 
What type of poverty analysis is needed?  
 
Basic poverty and social analysis is proposed. The project preparatory technical assistance (TA) will look at the 
incidence of poverty using existing data sources and supplement it through the social survey of potential beneficiaries. 
Both income and nonincome poverty indices will be determined. The analysis will be carried out following the 
Handbook on Poverty and Social Analysis and Handbook for Integrating Poverty Impact on Economic Analysis of 
Projects of the Asian Development Bank (ADB). Particular attention is to be given to profiling the beneficiaries, 
including gender disaggregated demographic, economic, and social data where possible, plus the incidence of 
poverty, vulnerable groups, and any adverse impacts anticipated from the proposed project. 
 
C.  Participation Process 
 
Is there a stakeholder analysis?    Yes     No  
 
A stakeholder analysis will be prepared as part of the TA. Participatory workshops will be held to strengthen the 
participatory approach. A workshop will be held for stakeholders to discuss and agree on the strategic plan, and the 
proposed ADB investment project. More intensive focus group meetings, interviews, and surveys will be held with local 
government agencies, development partners, nongovernment organizations, private sector, and identified project 
beneficiaries.  
 
Is there a participation strategy?     Yes                   No 
 
A participation strategy will be prepared as part of the TA. This strategy will aim to ensure the involvement of local 
government and communities, and particularly the poor, women, ethnic minorities, and vulnerable groups. The 
participation and consultation strategy will be adopted for engaging with people who might be adversely affected by 
the proposed project. 
 
D.  Gender Development 
  
Strategy to maximize impacts on women: 
 
The TA will assess measures to ensure gender equality. A strategy will be prepared, as required, to address impacts 
on women from the proposed project.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
 
1.  District  Heating  Specialists  (one  international:  7  person-months,  one  national:  6 
person-months, and one national: 3 person-months).The international district heating specialist 
will  act  as  team  leader  and  coordinate  communication  between  the  consultants  and  the 
government of the Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region (GIMAR), the Executing Agency; the 
implementing agencies; and Asian Development Bank (ADB). The specialists will undertake the 
following: 
 
(i)  Prepare a summary of the current status of the central heating subsector in the 
People’s  Republic  of  China  (PRC)  and  Inner  Mongolia  Autonomous  Region 
(IMAR).  Carry  out  least-cost  district  heating  planning  in  IMAR;  discuss  the 
assumptions, methodology, computer models, and completeness of data used; 
and present an analysis of the results of these studies.  
(ii)  Verify and confirm that the proposed project is part of the least-cost expansion 
plan.  Determine  and  provide  full  technical  justification  for  the  project  and 
compare  with  possible  alternatives.  Review  background  data  and  feasibility 
reports  for  each  district  heating  subproject  and,  if  possible,  present  specific 
suggestions  for  improvement  and  finalization  of  project  design.  Validate  the 
technical assumptions made in the feasibility reports, and review heating demand 
projections.  
(iii)  Assess affordability issues related to heating supply for the poor. Recommend 
pro-poor activities that could be included in the project and would directly benefit 
the  poor  in  IMAR,  taking  into  account  proposals  of  GIMAR  and  project 
implementing agencies.  
(iv)  Assess and recommend options for each subproject for improving (a) demand-
side energy efficiency including tariff incentives, regulatory reforms, metering, 
and billing options; and (b) supply-side energy efficiency, including new heating 
distribution equipment technologies, and electronic monitoring technologies and 
management methodologies.  
(v)  Assess and quantify the energy efficiency improvements from the project, in 
particular  the  projected  contribution  to  IMAR  energy  efficiency  improvement 
targets.  
(vi)  Review  the  cost  estimates,  including  identifying  local  and  foreign  cost 
components and physical and price contingencies. Present the cost estimates in 
ADB  format.  Review  GIMAR’s  proposed  contract  packaging  and  suggest 
improvements, taking into account efficiency in procurement and the estimated 
base  costs  for  each  package.  Determine  the  financing  requirements  of  the 
project in terms of local cost and foreign exchange requirements.  
(vii)  Prepare (a) an outline bidding document that can be used for preparing the 
bidding documents once the detailed engineering of the project is completed; (b) 
the implementation schedule showing the project’s critical path and the timing for 
each activity; and (c) a project procurement schedule, giving the key milestone 
dates.  Assess  the  technical  and  institutional  capacity  of  the  implementing 
agencies.  
(viii)  Recommend,  where  required,  changes  to  the  institutional  structures  of  the 
implementing agencies to improve technical and institutional capacity for project 
implementation.  Identify  their  technical  training  needs,  and  design  training 
programs  to  improve  technical  and  institutional  capacity.  Conduct  targeted 
capacity-building training activities for the implementing agencies.

to the consultation and participation plan.  
(xiii)  Summarize external assistance from multilateral development banks and other 
development agencies to the heating subsector in IMAR. Liaise with the clean 
energy  hub  at  Tsinghua  University  to  discuss  project  benefits.  Assess  the 
performance of the external assistance and identified lessons.  
(xiv)  Prepare the detailed design and monitoring framework, including stakeholder 
analysis,  problem  and  objectives  tree  (involving  key  stakeholders),  and 
alternatives analysis. Analyze lessons from previous and similar projects.  
 
2.  Private  Sector  Development  Specialists (one international: 2 person-months, one 
national: 4 person-months, and one national: 2 person-months) will undertake the following: 
 
(i)  Review and assess current status of private sector participation in district heating 
in IMAR; and identify barriers: institutional, regulatory, financial, etc. in promoting 
private sector participation.  
(ii)  Undertake resource and skills audit of project companies to identify their financial 
and management capacity, and prepare a comprehensive capacity enhancement 
program to bridge identified skills and resource gaps. Conduct targeted capacity-
building training activities for the implementing agencies. Review and assess 
commercialization in existing operations of project companies, and develop an 
enterprise reform plan and a time-bound action plan for project companies to 
prepare for commercialization of their operations. Identify, prioritize, and rank 
areas of operation for divestment. Prepare an action plan for divestment for the 
first rank area, evaluating options for divestment.  
(iii)  Prepare detailed case studies of successful private sector participation in district 
heating  in  IMAR  for  dissemination  to  local  governments  and  local  financial 
institutions.  Conduct  a  series  of  meetings  with  local  governments  and  local 
financial institutions to discuss expansion of private sector participation in the 
heating subsector. 
 
3.  Financial and Institutional Analysts (one international: 2 person-months, one national 
4 person-months, and one national: 2 person-months) will undertake the following: 
 
(i)  Conduct a detailed review of the audited and unaudited financial statements of 
the implementing agencies for the past 5 years to assess (a) historical financial 
performance, (b) retail tariffs, (c) capital structure, and (d) sufficient generation of 
internal funds to support sustainability of ongoing operations (i.e., the ability to 
service  existing  debts  and  to  finance  a  reasonable  proportion  of  capital 
expenditures).  
(ii)  Prepare projected financial statements (balance sheet, income statement, and 
statement of cash flows) for 10 years, and recommend key financial indicators 
and covenants. Prepare project cost estimates for all implementing agencies and 
the  project  as  a  whole,  taking  into  account  all  relevant  financial  costs  and

Appendix 4  13 
benefits.  Prepare  a  financing  plan,  including  proposed  ADB  lending,  any 
prospective cofinancing, and appropriate counterpart funds.  
(iii)  Carry out an in-depth financial analysis of all subprojects, including calculation of 
the financial internal rate of return and weighted average cost of capital. Identify 
project revenue and cost risks, conduct relevant sensitivity analyses, and identify 
practical strategies and approaches to mitigate the risks.  
(iv)  Prepare relevant appendices and tables for the report and recommendation of 
the President.  
(v)  Assess the financial management capabilities and internal controls of GIMAR 
and  the  implementing  agencies,  and  make  recommendations  for  institutional 
strengthening with a time-bound action plan.  
(vi)  Design the fund-flow mechanism and identify appropriate ADB disbursement 
procedures,  based  on  the  project  needs  and  capacity  of  GIMAR  and  the 
implementing agencies to manage funds flow.  
(vii)  Review and assess the institutional arrangements in the heating subsector, and 
the current status of private sector participation in the various subproject sectors; 
identify  the  barriers  to  private  sector  participation;  and  develop,  where 
appropriate, enterprise reform plans to prepare the implementing agencies for 
commercialization. 
 
4.  Economic Analysts (one international: 2 person-months and one national: 4 person-
months) will undertake the following: 
 
(i)  Provide general macro and sector information, including energy production and 
consumption  by  sector,  energy  efficiency,  and  heating  production  and 
consumption by sector for the PRC and IMAR. Analyze the sectoral and policy 
context of the project. Provide an independent assessment of the short-term (3 
years)  and  long-term  (system  planning  period)  demand  forecasts.  Analyze 
government policies that may have significant impact on the demand and supply 
of energy. Provide a detailed discussion of the assumptions and methodology 
used in demand forecasting.  
(ii)  Provide quantitative and qualitative benefits of the project and its components.  
(iii)  Carry  out  an  economic  analysis,  specifically  including  (a)  heating  demand 
analysis,  (b)  least-cost  and  equalizing  discount  rate  analysis,  (c) economic 
viability analysis, and (d) risk analysis. Discuss alternative methodologies for 
carrying out the economic analysis.  
(iv)  Describe how the heating tariffs for the project components will be determined. 
Assess the willingness to pay for heating by consumers in the project area in 
consultation  with  the  social/poverty  specialist,  based  on  a  sample  survey  of 
energy consumed, price paid by households, and household income.  
(v)  Calculate the energy efficiency improvements to the IMAR heating subsector 
from  the  project.  Analyze  the  impact  from  the  project  to  the  IMAR  energy 
efficiency targets under the 11th Five-Year Plan.  
(vi)  Incorporate  into  the  economic  analysis  an  economic  quantification  of 
environmental impact due to the project following ADB’s Economic Valuation of 
Environmental  Impacts:  A  Workbook  (1996),  and  Environmental  Assessment 
Guidelines (2003). Discuss the assumptions and economic parameters used in 
the economic analysis, including the assumed consumers’ willingness to pay and 
resource cost savings in relation to alternative options.

14  Appendix 4 
(vii)  Calculate an economic internal rate of return for the subproject. Identify and 
analyze likely economic uncertainties that could affect the project's viability, and 
carry out a risk analysis. Conduct a sensitivity analysis for plausible scenarios.  
(viii)  For project monitoring purposes, develop a set of performance indicators (in 
coordination  with  other  relevant  technical  experts)  that  can  be  verified  and 
monitored  (including  operating,  financial,  environmental,  socioeconomic,  and 
poverty reduction parameters). Specify baseline targets for socioeconomic and 
poverty  indicators  and  a  sustainable  mechanism  for  monitoring  during  and 
beyond the construction stage.  
(ix)  Prepare  the  following  appendices  to  the  report  and  recommendation  of  the 
President: (i) project economic analysis, including demand forecast, least-cost 
analysis,  economic  internal  rate  of  return,  environmental  benefits,  and  risk 
analysis, (ii) environmental economic benefits analysis, and (iii) sector analysis.  
 
5.  Geothermal Specialists (one international; 1 person-month and one national: 4 person-
months). The specialists will have the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Prepare a brief summary of the current status of the geothermal subsector in the 
PRC and IMAR. Include a summary of the existing regulatory framework for 
development of geothermal resources. Review existing hydrogeological resource 
assessment  reports  and  other  studies  conducted  at  the  Nincheng  site,  and 
recommend  additional  studies  required  for  assessing  geothermal  resources. 
Assess technical and financial alternatives for utilization of geothermal resources 
in Nincheng County, including district heating, electricity generation, tourism, and 
aquaculture/horticulture developments.  
(ii)  Review  proposed  geothermal  utilization  design,  and  provide  technical 
recommendations  on  subproject  design.  Ensure  that  the  proposed  design 
provides  for  sustainable  use  of  the  geothermal  resources.  Review  financial 
assessments of the geothermal utilization design to confirm technical viability and 
that it is the least-cost alternative.  
(iii)  Review  geothermal  technical  capacity  of  the  implementing  agencies,  and 
recommend  institutional  capacity-building  requirements.  Conduct  targeted 
capacity-building training activities for the implementing agencies. 
 
6.  Natural Gas Distribution Specialist (one national: 2 person-months). The specialist will 
have the following responsibilities: 
 
(i)  Prepare a brief summary of the current status of the natural gas subsector in 
IMAR. Review background data and feasibility reports prepared for the natural 
gas subproject and, if possible, present specific suggestions for improvement 
and finalization of project design. Validate the technical assumptions made in the 
feasibility  reports,  and  review  demand  projections.  Carry  out  least-cost 
assessment  of  the  proposed  subproject  and  confirm  that  the  design  for  the 
natural gas component is part of the least-cost expansion plan.  
(ii)  Determine  and  provide  the  full  technical  justification  for  the  subproject  and 
compare with possible alternatives.  
(iii)  Assess the technical and institutional capacity of the implementing agencies; and 
recommend, where required, changes to the implementing agencies’ institutional 
structures to improve technical and institutional implementation capacity. Identify 
technical  training  needs  for  the  implementing  agencies,  and  design  training 
programs to improve technical and institutional capacity.

Appendix 4  15 
(iv)  Assess the likely technical risks facing the various aspects of the natural gas 
component of the project, and carry out sensitivity analysis to check the viability 
of the project. 
  
7.  Environment  Specialists  (one  international:  1  person-month  and  one  national:  4 
person-months). The specialists will undertake the following: 
 
(i)  Review the draft environmental impact assessment (EIA) to ensure it conforms to 
ADB’s Environment Policy (2002) and Environmental Assessment Guidelines 
(2003). Carry out further investigations and analysis, as required, to ensure that 
the draft EIA complies with ADB’s environment policy and guidelines.  
(ii)  Prepare  the  summary  EIA  or  summary  initial  environmental  examination, 
depending on the environmental classification.  
(iii)  Quantify the environmental benefits from project implementation, including (a) 
energy efficiency improvements, (b) reductions in air emissions, and (c) other 
environmental benefits. Identify appropriate monitoring parameters, suitable for 
incorporation into the project performance monitoring system. Assess (a) global 
environmental benefits in terms of reduction of greenhouse gas emissions, and 
eligibility for the Clean Development Mechanism under the Kyoto Protocol.  
(iv)  Carry  out  the  following  activities:  (a)  review  the  environmental  management 
capabilities  of  GIMAR  and  the  local  environmental  monitoring  units,  and 
recommend  institutional  strengthening  measures,  if  required;  (b)  conduct 
additional environmental public consultation activities, as required, in accordance 
with ADB Environmental Assessment Guidelines (2003); (c) estimate costs of the 
proposed  environmental  mitigation  measures  and  implementation  of  the 
environmental monitoring plan; (d) assist the design engineers in incorporating 
appropriate mitigation measures into the project design; and (e) prepare terms of 
reference and a budget for independent environmental monitoring activities.  
 
8.  Social and Resettlement Specialists (one national: 4 person-months and one national: 
2 person-months). The specialists will undertake the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Conduct a site visit to verify the initial poverty and social assessment.  
(ii)  Collect available reports and published statistics that are relevant to the project. 
Identify the project stakeholders and examine their existing rights and possible 
risks from the project. Assist in building public acceptance of the project.  
(iii)  Organize and conduct surveys in the project area, and consult with GIMAR and 
non government organizations to supplement secondary data. Prepare a poverty 
profile of the project area.  
(iv)  Conduct stakeholder consultation activities, as necessary. Indicate the poverty 
incidence, current situation, and trends; include characteristics of poverty and the 
perceptions of people gathered through surveys or existing poverty assessments 
of the project area. Assess the pro-poor impacts, taking into account linkage 
effects. Identify ways to make the project pro-poor, design a time-bound plan for 
monitoring,  and  outline  the  plan  and  resources  required  to  implement  the 
monitoring plan. Estimate the number of poor people who will benefit from the 
project. Estimate the proportion of the poor who will benefit from government 
expenditure. Where the Government will have a net cost, estimate the proportion 
of marginal tax revenue derived from the poor. For net benefits to the economy, 
estimate the proportion directly benefiting the poor. Provide a statement of the 
project features relating to poverty reduction.

16  Appendix 4 
(v)  Assess  the  social  and  gender  considerations  as  part  of  the  project  design. 
Prepare a social analysis in accordance with ADB’s Handbook on Poverty and 
Social Analysis. Determine the likely social and gender effects, such as any 
joblessness  created  by  closing  old  boilers  in  IMAR.  Assess  need  for  a 
reemployment plan and prepare as required. Identify any mitigation measures or 
complementary activity that could help reduce poverty in the project area.  
(vi)  Assess impact on ethnic minorities through culturally appropriate consultation 
methods  with  potentially  affected  ethnic  minorities.  Recommend  culturally 
appropriate  measures  to  address  these  impacts/effects,  and  assess  if these 
measures could appropriately be covered by the main project design or if an 
ethnic minority development plan needs to be formulated in consultation with the 
affected  ethnic  minorities.  Determine  possible  socioeconomic  and  cultural 
impacts on ethnic minorities, if any, arising from changes in energy generation 
and consumption patterns.  
(vii)  Investigate whether the project will require land acquisition, changes in land use, 
or  restricted  access  to  land  and  natural  resources;  and  if  required,  prepare 
subproject resettlement plan/s and/or resettlement framework in accordance with 
ADB's  policy  on  Involuntary  Resettlement  (1995)  and  OMF2  on  involuntary 
resettlement (2006).  
(viii)  Design tariff assistance programs that are consistent with ADB policy requiring 
that tariff subsidies to the poor be transparent and explicit, and funded by the 
government budget, which will separate the welfare objectives from commercial 
management of the public utilities.  
(ix)  Identify relevant indicators, methodology, plan and timing, location, and human 
resource requirements to analyze poverty impact. Incorporate indicators into the 
project performance monitoring system. 
 
9.  Project Monitoring Specialist (one national: 5 person-months). The specialist will have 
the following responsibilities: 
 
(i)  Review the project-related documents to determine a set of monitoring indicators 
in  the  areas  of  economic  growth,  energy  efficiency,  and  environmental 
improvement. Assess data availability for determining the indicators.  
(ii)  Determine a feedback and reporting mechanism for effective project preparatory 
TA project implementation and management.  
(iii)  Prepare a framework for initial project preparatory TA start-up activities. Assist in 
coordinating site visits and collating data from field teams.  
(iv)  Collect and analyze all relevant reports and studies pertaining to the heating 
subsector in IMAR, including annual production and sales data, investments in, 
employment and productivity, and restructuring. Ensure that all relevant reports 
are made available to the international and national consultants and, if necessary, 
translate them into English.  
(v)  Arrange and coordinate the required meetings and visits for the international and 
national consultants, and translate consultants’ main reports into Chinese.  
(vi)  Help with the technical, financial, economic, environmental, and poverty impact 
evaluation.
